unitTitle: Health and safety in building services engineering
loTitle: Understand how relevant legislation applies in the workplace
assessmentCriteria: Identify roles and responsibilities re: current relevant H&S legislation
Identify roles and responsibilities re: current relevant environmental legislation
content:
## LO1 — Understand how relevant legislation applies in the workplace
**Assessment criteria**
1. Identify roles and responsibilities re: current relevant H&S legislation
2. Identify roles and responsibilities re: current relevant environmental legislation

**Range**
- Roles: Employers; Employees; Organisations; Clients
- Relevant H&S legislation (examples):
- Health and Safety at Work Act
- Electricity at Work Regulations
- Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations
- Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations
- COSHH Regulations
- Working at Height Regulations
- PPE at Work Regulations
- Manual Handling Operations Regulations
- PUWER
- Control of Asbestos at Work Regulations
- Relevant environmental legislation (examples):
- Control of Asbestos at Work Regulations
- Environmental Protection Act
- Hazardous Waste Regulations
- Pollution Prevention and Control Act
- Control of Pollution Act
- Control of Noise at Work Regulations
- WEEE Regulations

---

unitTitle: Health and safety in building services engineering
loTitle: Procedures for dealing with environmental and H&S situations
assessmentCriteria: Procedures for accidents involving injury (incl. electric shock / electrical burns)
Procedures for workplace emergencies
Actions when situations exceed own level of responsibility
Responsible persons to report H&S/welfare matters to
Ways the environment may be affected by work activities
Current requirements + good practice for processing waste on site
Why environmental hazards arising from work procedures must be reported
content:
## LO2 — Procedures for dealing with environmental and H&S situations
**Assessment criteria**
1. Procedures for accidents involving injury (incl. electric shock / electrical burns)
2. Procedures for workplace emergencies
3. Actions when situations exceed own level of responsibility
4. Responsible persons to report H&S/welfare matters to
5. Ways the environment may be affected by work activities
6. Current requirements + good practice for processing waste on site
7. Why environmental hazards arising from work procedures must be reported

**Range**
- Appropriate procedures:
- Summoning emergency services; info required
- Alarm/evacuation procedures; escape routes
- Fire-fighting procedures
- First aid
- RIDDOR reporting procedure
- Responsible persons:
- Employer; Employees; Customer/client; Safety officers
- H&S Executive/inspectors; Trades union rep
- Environmental health officers
- Environmental effects:
- Land contamination; air pollution; watercourse pollution
- Waste handling good practice:
- Recycling; hazardous waste; landfill

---

unitTitle: Health and safety in building services engineering
loTitle: Establishing a safe working environment (demonstrate and understand)
assessmentCriteria: Procedure for producing risk assessments and method statements (within own responsibility)
Procedures to remove/minimise risks before deciding PPE is needed
Purpose of PPE
Appropriate protective clothing/equipment for identified tasks
First aid facilities required in the work area
Why not to misuse first aid equipment; replace supplies when used
Safe practices/procedures for use of equipment and materials
Procedures for ensuring electrical systems are safe to work on
Implications of:
content:
## LO3 — Establishing a safe working environment (demonstrate and understand)
**Assessment criteria**
1. Procedure for producing risk assessments and method statements (within own responsibility)
2. Procedures to remove/minimise risks before deciding PPE is needed
3. Purpose of PPE
4. Appropriate protective clothing/equipment for identified tasks
5. First aid facilities required in the work area
6. Why not to misuse first aid equipment; replace supplies when used
7. Safe practices/procedures for use of equipment and materials
8. Procedures for ensuring electrical systems are safe to work on
9. Implications of:
- carrying out safe isolation procedures
- not carrying out safe isolation procedures

**Range**
- Procedures:
- Responsible persons; competent persons
- Safe isolation procedures
- Permits to work
- Selecting/checking correct power tools/hand tools/portable electrical equipment
- Equipment/materials:
- Access equipment (PASMA requirements)
- Portable power tools (e.g., drills, grinders)
- Storage facilities for tools/materials
- Dangerous substances (e.g., cutting compounds, adhesives)
- Ladders; mobile scaffold towers
- Signs and guarding
- Implications: Self; others; building systems

---

unitTitle: Health and safety in building services engineering
assessmentCriteria: Identify warning pictograms for hazardous substances (GB CLP Regulation)
Define “hazard” in relation to H&S legislation
Identify hazards associated with installing/maintaining electrical systems/equipment
Describe situations that can constitute a hazard
Explain practices/procedures for addressing hazards (inferred through practical)
Identify correct fire extinguisher type for a given fire type
Explain situations where asbestos may be encountered
Procedures for suspected asbestos presence
content:
## LO4 — Identifying and dealing with hazards
**Assessment criteria**
1. Identify warning pictograms for hazardous substances (GB CLP Regulation)
2. Define “hazard” in relation to H&S legislation
3. Identify hazards associated with installing/maintaining electrical systems/equipment
4. Describe situations that can constitute a hazard
5. Explain practices/procedures for addressing hazards (inferred through practical)
6. Identify correct fire extinguisher type for a given fire type
7. Explain situations where asbestos may be encountered
8. Procedures for suspected asbestos presence

**Range**
- Specific hazards: Electric shock (direct/indirect contact); burns; fires; explosions
- Situations/hazards in the workplace:
- Temporary electrical supplies; trailing leads/cables
- Slippery/uneven surfaces; dust/fumes
- Handling/transporting equipment/materials
- Contaminants/irritants; fire; working at height
- Hazardous malfunctions; improper use/maintenance/storage of tools/equipment
- Bacteria: Weil’s disease
- Where asbestos may be encountered:
- Decorative finishes (artex, plaster, floor tiles)
- Accessories (flash guards/matting in fuse carriers; DB covers)
- Insulation storage compartments, vessels, pipework
- Use of signs to warn of hazards

---

## Unit 201 — supporting information
**Notes for guidance:** Emphasise keeping up-to-date with standards, technologies, and practices (good engineering practice).
**Assessment:** Mandatory components **(211) assignment** and **(601) online evolve test**.

---

unitTitle: Principles of Electrical Science
assessmentCriteria: Identify and apply appropriate mathematical principles relevant to electrical work tasks
content:
## LO1 — Mathematical principles for electrical work
**AC**
1. Identify and apply appropriate mathematical principles relevant to electrical work tasks

**Range:** Fractions/percentages; algebra; indices; transposition; triangles/trigonometry; statistics.

---

unitTitle: Principles of Electrical Science
assessmentCriteria: Identify and use internationally recognised base and derived (SI) units
Identify/determine values of base and derived SI units for electrical quantities
Identify appropriate instruments for measuring different electrical quantities
content:
## LO2 — Standard units of measurement
**AC**
1. Identify and use internationally recognised base and derived (SI) units
2. Identify/determine values of base and derived SI units for electrical quantities
3. Identify appropriate instruments for measuring different electrical quantities

**Range**
- SI units for: length; area; volume; mass; density; time; temperature; velocity
- Electrical quantities (SI): resistance; resistivity; power; frequency; current; voltage; energy; impedance; inductance/inductive reactance; capacitance/capacitive reactance; power factor
- Electrical quantities (measurement): resistance; power; current; voltage; energy

---

unitTitle: Principles of Electrical Science
assessmentCriteria: Specify mass vs weight
Explain basic mechanics as applied to levers, gears, pulleys
Describe principles and relationships of: force; work; energy (kinetic/potential); power; efficiency
Calculate mechanical energy, power, efficiency
content:
## LO3 — Basic mechanics (force/work/energy/power)
**AC**
1. Specify mass vs weight
2. Explain basic mechanics as applied to levers, gears, pulleys
3. Describe principles and relationships of: force; work; energy (kinetic/potential); power; efficiency
4. Calculate mechanical energy, power, efficiency

**Range:** Levers — class I, II, III.

---

unitTitle: Principles of Electrical Science
assessmentCriteria: Basic electron theory
Conductors vs insulators
Meaning of resistance and resistivity (in circuits)
Relationship between current/voltage/resistance in series & parallel D.C. circuits
Calculate current/voltage/resistance in series & parallel D.C. circuits
Calculate power in series & parallel D.C. circuits
Meaning of voltage drop
Chemical and thermal effects of electric currents
content:
## LO4 — Resistance, resistivity, voltage, current, power
**AC**
1. Basic electron theory
2. Conductors vs insulators
3. Meaning of resistance and resistivity (in circuits)
4. Relationship between current/voltage/resistance in series & parallel D.C. circuits
5. Calculate current/voltage/resistance in series & parallel D.C. circuits
6. Calculate power in series & parallel D.C. circuits
7. Meaning of voltage drop
8. Chemical and thermal effects of electric currents

---

unitTitle: Principles of Electrical Science
assessmentCriteria: Effects of magnetism (attraction/repulsion)
Difference between magnetic flux and flux density
Magnetic effects of electrical currents:
Generating an A.C. supply:
Identify characteristics of sine-waves
content:
## LO5 — Magnetism and electricity relationship
**AC**
1. Effects of magnetism (attraction/repulsion)
2. Difference between magnetic flux and flux density
3. Magnetic effects of electrical currents:
- magnetic field production
- force on current-carrying conductor in magnetic field
- electromagnetism
- electromotive force (EMF)
4. Generating an A.C. supply:
- single-loop generator
- sine-wave
- frequency
- EMF
- magnetic flux
5. Identify characteristics of sine-waves

**Range (sine-wave characteristics):** RMS value; average value; peak-to-peak value; periodic time; frequency; amplitude.

---

unitTitle: Principles of Electrical Science
assessmentCriteria: Function and application of electronic components used in electrical systems
Basic operating principles of electronic components/devices
content:
## LO6 — Electronic components in systems/equipment
**AC**
1. Function and application of electronic components used in electrical systems
2. Basic operating principles of electronic components/devices

**Range**
- Electrical systems: security alarms; telephones; dimmer switches; heating/boiler controls; motor control; wireless control systems
- Electronic components/devices: capacitors; resistors; rectifiers; diodes; zener; LED; photo; thermistors; diacs; triacs; transistors; thyristors; inverters

---

## Unit 202 — supporting information
**Notes for guidance:** Emphasise keeping up-to-date with standards, technologies, practices (good engineering practice).
**Assessment:** Mandatory component **(602) evolve test**.

---

unitTitle: Electrical installations technology
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify statutory regulations
2 Identify non-statutory regulations/guidance
3 State implications of statutory regulations
4 State implications of non-statutory regulations
content:
## LO1 — Implications of electrical industry regulations
**AC**
1.1 Identify statutory regulations
1.2 Identify non-statutory regulations/guidance
1.3 State implications of statutory regulations
1.4 State implications of non-statutory regulations

**Range**
- Statutory regulations: HASAWA; EAWR; ESQCR; PUWER; COSHH; CDM; Manual Handling; PPE; Noise at Work; Environmental Act; DDA; Equal Opportunities
- Non-statutory: BS 7671; On-Site Guide; Unite Union Book; Guidance Notes; Codes of Practice
- Implications: prosecution; fines; imprisonment; prohibition/improvement notices; dismissal; injury/death; loss of earnings/clients; reputational damage

---

unitTitle: Electrical installations technology
assessmentCriteria: 1 State purpose of different sources of technical information
2 Recognise drawing types
3 Recognise symbols used in drawings
4 Convert drawing scale to actual dimensions
content:
## LO2 — Obtaining technical information
**AC**
2.1 State purpose of different sources of technical information
2.2 Recognise drawing types
2.3 Recognise symbols used in drawings
2.4 Convert drawing scale to actual dimensions

**Range**
- Sources: specifications (material selection); drawings (wiring system info); BS 7671/On-Site Guide; Unite Union Book; manufacturer data; Guidance Notes; client needs
- Drawing types: as-fitted drawings; circuit diagrams; block diagrams; schematics; wiring diagrams; bar charts
- Symbols (examples): switching (1-way, 2-way, intermediate, pull); switched/unswitched socket outlets; FCUs and switched FCUs; lighting points (fluorescent, incandescent, LED, wall); cooker control unit; consumer control unit; integrated meter; fuse; circuit breaker

---

unitTitle: Electrical installations technology
assessmentCriteria: 1 Describe principles of operation of circuit types
2 Identify wiring systems for different environments
3 Determine minimum current-carrying capacity of live conductors for given conditions
4 State applications of protective device types
5 Identify purpose of specialised equipment for installing wiring systems
6 Calculate spacing factor of wiring enclosures
content:
## LO3 — Wiring systems of electrical installations
**AC**
3.1 Describe principles of operation of circuit types
3.2 Identify wiring systems for different environments
3.3 Determine minimum current-carrying capacity of live conductors for given conditions
3.4 State applications of protective device types
3.5 Identify purpose of specialised equipment for installing wiring systems
3.6 Calculate spacing factor of wiring enclosures

**Range**
- Circuit types: lighting; power/heating; alarm/emergency; data comms; control circuits; ring final; radial
- Wiring systems: tray; trunking; conduit; ladder racking; thermoplastic multicore; flat profile; SWA; MICC; fire resistant; thermoplastic single-core; support methods/requirements; component parts
- Environments: domestic; commercial; hazardous; industrial; agricultural
- Installation conditions: Ib, In, Iz, It, Ca, Cc, Cf, Cg, Ci; voltage drop; methods of installation
- Protective devices:
- fuses: BS 88 (gM, gG), BS 3036
- circuit breakers: BS EN 60898 types B/C/D
- RCD: BS EN 61008
- RCBO: BS EN 61009 types B/C/D
- Specialised equipment: conduit/tray benders; stocks; dies; formers
- Wiring enclosures: conduit; trunking

---

unitTitle: Electrical installations technology
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify earthing system types
2 Identify ADS component parts
3 Identify exposed conductive parts
4 Identify extraneous conductive parts
5 Identify components of an earth loop impedance path
content:
## LO4 — Requirements for earthing systems
**AC**
4.1 Identify earthing system types
4.2 Identify ADS component parts
4.3 Identify exposed conductive parts
4.4 Identify extraneous conductive parts
4.5 Identify components of an earth loop impedance path

**Range**
- Earthing systems: TT; TN-S; TN-C-S
- ADS components: CPC; main protective bonding; supplementary bonding; earthing conductor; protective devices; earth electrode
- Exposed conductive parts: steel conduit/trunking/tray; steel enclosures; metal accessories; metallic equipment
- Extraneous conductive parts: metallic gas/oil/water pipes; steel ductwork; structural steel
- Earth loop impedance path components: Zs; Ze; R1; R2; MET; supplier earth return path

---

unitTitle: Electrical installations technology
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify generation methods for distribution
2 Identify transmission voltages
3 Identify distribution voltages
4 State components of the distribution network
content:
## LO5 — How electricity is supplied
**AC**
5.1 Identify generation methods for distribution
5.2 Identify transmission voltages
5.3 Identify distribution voltages
5.4 State components of the distribution network

**Range**
- Generation: coal; oil; biomass; wind; wave; hydro; nuclear; photovoltaic; gas; micro-generation
- Transmission voltages: 400 kV; 275 kV; 132 kV
- Distribution voltages: 33 kV; 11 kV; 400/230 V
- Network components: substations; pylons; power stations; cables; insulators; transformers

---

unitTitle: Electrical installations technology
assessmentCriteria: 1 Describe types of micro-renewable energy
2 Identify installation requirements
3 Identify advantages/disadvantages
content:
## LO6 — Micro-renewable energies
**AC**
6.1 Describe types of micro-renewable energy
6.2 Identify installation requirements
6.3 Identify advantages/disadvantages

**Range**
- Types: solar thermal; ground-source heat pump; air-source heat pump; biomass; solar PV; micro-wind; micro-hydro; micro-CHP (heat-led); rainwater harvesting; greywater re-use
- Requirements: legal; regulatory; location

---

unitTitle: Installation of wiring systems and enclosures
loTitle: Tools used to install wiring systems
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify hand tools for tasks
2 Identify power tools for tasks
3 Describe safety checks for tools
content:
## LO1 — Tools used to install wiring systems
**AC**
1.1 Identify hand tools for tasks
1.2 Identify power tools for tasks
1.3 Describe safety checks for tools

**Range**
- Hand tools: rules; levels; gauges; plumb lines; cable cutters; screwdrivers; wire strippers; knife; files; reamers; wrenches; hammer; saws
- Power tools: drill; hammer drill; pillar drill; electric screwdriver
- Safety checks: safe to use; correct speed; correct attachments fitted correctly; guards in place; correct PPE; best performance (sharp)

---

unitTitle: Installation of wiring systems and enclosures
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify hazards in the workspace
2 Identify PPE for tasks
3 Select access equipment
content:
## LO2 — Preparing for installing wiring systems
**AC**
2.1 Identify hazards in the workspace
2.2 Identify PPE for tasks
2.3 Select access equipment

**Range**
- Hazards: circuit isolation; safe working practices; risk assessment/method statement
- PPE: hard hat; safety glasses; safety shoes; gloves; ear defenders; protective work wear
- Access equipment: ladders; platforms; hop-up

---

unitTitle: Installation of wiring systems and enclosures
assessmentCriteria: 1 Select materials from drawings
2 Mark out dimensions from drawings
3 Fix accessories to drawing dimensions
4 Install wiring systems and supports
5 Terminate wiring systems
6 Maintain safe working practices
7 Use JIB safe isolation procedures
content:
## LO3 — Install wiring systems
**AC**
3.1 Select materials from drawings
3.2 Mark out dimensions from drawings
3.3 Fix accessories to drawing dimensions
3.4 Install wiring systems and supports
3.5 Terminate wiring systems
3.6 Maintain safe working practices
3.7 Use JIB safe isolation procedures

**Range (wiring systems):**
- Single & multicore thermoplastic cable
- Fire resistant cable
- Data cable
- Multicore armoured cable
- Cable tray
- Cable conduit (steel and PVC)
- Cable trunking

---

unitTitle: Installation of wiring systems and enclosures
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify cable sizes
2 Terminate cables
3 Connect bonding clamps
4 Test continuity
content:
## LO4 — Bond mains services to MET
**AC**
4.1 Identify cable sizes
4.2 Terminate cables
4.3 Connect bonding clamps
4.4 Test continuity

unitTitle: Installation of wiring systems and enclosures
assessmentCriteria: 1 Verify wiring systems conform to IET standards
content:
## LO5 — Inspect a “dead” electrical installation
**AC**
5.1 Verify wiring systems conform to IET standards

---

unitTitle: Installation of wiring systems and enclosures
assessmentCriteria: 1 Test CPC continuity
2 Test ring final circuit
3 Test insulation resistance
4 Test polarity
5 Test functionality
6 Record test results
content:
## LO6 — Test a “dead” electrical installation
**AC**
6.1 Test CPC continuity
6.2 Test ring final circuit
6.3 Test insulation resistance
6.4 Test polarity
6.5 Test functionality
6.6 Record test results

**Range (functionality):**
- Switches/devices by movement
- Continuity test
- Live (under supervision)

---

unitTitle: Communicate with others within building services engineering
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify key roles of the site management team:
2 Identify key roles of individuals reporting to site management:
3 Identify key roles of site visitors:
content:
## LO1 — Construction team members and roles
**AC**
1.1 Identify key roles of the site management team:
- architect; project manager/clerk of works; structural engineer; surveyor; building services engineer; quantity surveyor; buyer; estimator; contracts manager; construction manager

1.2 Identify key roles of individuals reporting to site management:
- subcontractors; site supervisor; trade supervisor
- trades: bricklayer; joiner; plasterer; tiler; electrician; H&V fitter; gas fitter; decorator; ground workers

1.3 Identify key roles of site visitors:
- building control inspector; water inspector; HSE inspector; electrical services inspector

---

unitTitle: Communicate with others within building services engineering
loTitle: Apply information sources in the building services industry
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify types of statutory legislation and guidance info:
2 Identify purpose of workplace information:
3 Identify purpose of customer information:
4 State importance of company policies/procedures affecting working relationships:
content:
## LO2 — Apply information sources in the building services industry
**AC**
2.1 Identify types of statutory legislation and guidance info:
- legislation (data protection; equal opportunities; health & safety; employment)
- regulations; British Standards; codes of practice
- manufacturer guidance (installation; service/maintenance; user instructions)

2.2 Identify purpose of workplace information:
- job specifications; plans/drawings; work programmes
- delivery notes; time sheets
- policy documentation (H&S; environmental; customer service)

2.3 Identify purpose of customer information:
- quotations; estimates; invoices/statements
- statutory cancellation rights
- handover information

2.4 State importance of company policies/procedures affecting working relationships:
- behaviour; timekeeping; dress code; contract of employment
- limits to personal authority (apprentices; level 2 staff; level 3 staff)
- supervisor/management responsibilities

---

unitTitle: Communicate with others within building services engineering
loTitle: Communicate with others in the industry
assessmentCriteria: 1 Identify suitable communication methods:
2 Define effective communication methods for people with:
3 State actions to deal with conflicts between:
4 State effects of poor communication on an organisation:
content:
## LO3 — Communicate with others in the industry
**AC**
3.1 Identify suitable communication methods:
- oral
- written (email; fax; letter)

3.2 Define effective communication methods for people with:
- physical disabilities
- learning difficulties
- language differences (dialects; accents; foreign/second language issues)

3.3 State actions to deal with conflicts between:
- customers and operatives
- co-workers
- supervisors and operatives

3.4 State effects of poor communication on an organisation:
- between operatives
- between operatives and management
- company to customer

## Links to other qualifications
This qualification has connections to:

- Level 2/3 NVQ in Plumbing and Heating (6189)
- Level 2/3 NVQ in Heating and Ventilating (6188)
- Level 2/3 NVQ in Refrigeration and Air Conditioning (6087)

- Level 2/3 Diploma in Heating and Ventilating (7188)
- Level 2/3 Diploma in Refrigeration, Air Conditioning and Heat Pump Systems (7189)
- Level 3 NVQ in Electrotechnical Services (2357)

## Literacy / language / numeracy / ICT
This qualification can develop skills for:
- Functional Skills (England)
- Essential Skills (Northern Ireland)
- Essential Skills Wales

---

# Appendix 2 — Disclaimer (candidate + tutor declaration)

This declaration must be completed as part of induction.

Key points:
- On completion, learner is at **Improver / Electrician’s Mate** level.
- To become a fully qualified Electrician, learner must meet National Occupational Standards (Summit Skills) via **C&G 2357 Level 3 NVQ Diploma in Electrotechnical Technology**, with performance units carried out in industry.
- Completion of 2357 enables application to an industry graded or competent person’s scheme.

Declaration statement:
> I understand that completing the 2365-02 Level 2 Diploma will not make me a fully qualified Electrician.

Sign-off:
- Candidate: ____  Date: ____
- Tutor: ____  Date: ____

---
